Roberts
Infobox State Representative
Colorado-Rep-Ellen-Roberts.jpg
Incumbent
attorney
150
Colorado
August 27, 1959 (1959-08-27) (age 49)
Republican
Presbyterian
200
Hudson, New York 2
Rick
Ellen Roberts
Mark Larson
January 10, 200782
59th
Colorado
Ellen Stuart Roberts1 (born August 27, 19592) is an attorney and first-term Republican legislator in the
U.S. state
of
Colorado
.
Raised in New York, Roberts pursued a career in environmental policy and worked as a park ranger before earning a law degree from the
University of Colorado
in 1986. Settling in
Durango, Colorado with her husband and two children, she was actively involved in local health care issues and local public works campaigns before running for the Colorado House of Representatives as a Republican in 2006. She was elected with 52 percent of the vote to represent House District 59, which encompasses
Archuleta County ,
La Plata County ,
San Juan County and parts of
Montezuma County in southwestern Colorado.3
A moderate Republican, Roberts has focused on health care and constitutional reform issues in the state legislature, and, despite being in the minority party, has seen almost all legislation she sponsored signed into law. She has also carried legislation to strengthen environmental rules surrounding oil and gas drilling, and to create a legislative youth advisory council. She is running unopposed for re-election in 2008.
Early career
Born in
Hudson, New York ,2 Roberts was raised in Rhinebeck, where she was elected class president in high school.4 She earned a self-designed undergraduate degree in environmental policy from
Cornell University in 1981.2 During college, she spent a semester as an intern in Washington DC, working for her Congressional representative and for the Republican National Committee.4 Despite an early desire to seek public office—she had once aspired to be Secretary of the Interior or run the National Parks Service—the experience caused her to become disillusioned with politics.4
She moved to Colorado upon graduation and worked as a ranger in
Rocky Mountain National Park until 1984.2 In 1982, Roberts married; she and her husband, Rick, have two children: Caitlin and Ben.
After being hired by a law firm in
Granby, Colorado , Roberts returned to school to earn a J.D. from the
University of Colorado
in 1986.2 She worked as an attorney in private practice in Grandby and
Hot Sulphur Springs ,4 specializing in estate, probate and business law.
A resident of
Durango, Colorado since 1989, She joined the Southwest Colorado Bar Association in 19862 and served as its president,1 and as president of the Southwest Colorado Women's Bar Association. As an attorney, Roberts advocated for increased legal services for immigrants and Spanish-speakers in southwestern Colorado5 and was critical of U.S. immigration law.6 She also served as legal counsel for the
Ute Mountain
Indian Housing Authority and the
Southern Ute
Indian Housing Authority.
Roberts began to re-enter politics after the death of her father in 1992, first focusing on hospice and health care issues.4 As a member (since 19997) and later chairman of the board of Mercy Regional Medical Center, she pushed for the construction of a new hospital in Durango.8 She chaired Healthy 58, a rural health care task force,7 and in 2001, was appointed to the Task Force to Evaluate Health Care Needs for Colorado, a commission formed by the legislature to study health-care needs in rural Colorado communities;9 she coordinated the task force's meeting in Durango.10
Roberts sat on the Sixth Judicial District Nominating Commission,11 and co-chaired the Durango Citizens Steering Committee for a New Library, a successful effort to push for a new local public library that was eventually built on the site of Mercy Medical Center, the hospital Roberts had worked to help replace.81213 She was a member of the High Noon Rotary Club, the Citizens Health Advisory Council, and sat on the boards of First National Bank2 and the Community Foundation Serving Southwest Colorado.14 In 2004, she won the Durango Chamber of Commerce's Athena Award for professional women in business.8
Legislative career
2006 election
As Representative Mark Larson neared the end of his term-limited tenure in the Colorado House of Representatives, Roberts began to work with him on learning the legislative process,8 in preparation for seeking elected office herself. She instigated a bill, introduced by Larson and eventually signed into law, to require that remains be handled in accordance with the wishes of the deceased.15 She lobbied the legislature, unsuccessfully, for the creation of an interim committee to study palliative care.1617
In December 2004, only a month after Larson was elected to his fourth and final term in the state house, Roberts filed for a 2006 candidacy to seek his seat.18 She announced her campaign formally in January 2005.19 She was endorsed by Larson,20 but initially faced a challenge for the Republican nomination from realtor Ron Tate,21 who was viewed as politically to her right.22 Tate later withdrew from the House primary to run for the Colorado State Senate,23 and Roberts won the Republican nomination unopposed.24 However, as a moderate Republican, she clashed with more conservative party leaders—a county Republican chair claimed that Roberts showed "no interest in supporting traditional family values" and she accused local conservative leaders of attempting to undermine her campaign.25 Among other conventionally "liberal" positions, she supports abortion rights, domestic partnerships for same-sex couples, and an increase in Colorado's minimum wage, and she was endorsed by Colorado Conservation Voters.26
During the general election campaign, Roberts emphasized her work on health care issues and her experience working with Representative Larson in the legislature, and criticized the passage of constitutional amendments creating conflicting fiscal obligations.272829 Although both Roberts and her main opponent, Democrat Joe Colgan, signed a clean campaign pledge, controversy arose over advertisements run by outside sources. In particular, Roberts denounced as "misleading" and "unacceptable" a television advertisement criticizing Colgan's record as mayor of Durango. The ad, which was run by a political group associated with the Colorado Association of Home Builders,30 was later pulled off the air.31 Direct mail flyers sent by right-leaning outside groups during the last weeks of the campaign also misrepresented both candidates' stances on immigration, exaggerating the contrast between their positions.32
In addition to her Democratic opponent, Roberts faced unaffiliated write-in candidate Christopher Navage. Navage withdrew from the race in October 2006 and endorsed Colgan.33 Roberts significantly outraised her opponents, donating over $8,000 to her own campaign,343536 and ultimately winning the November 2006 general election with 52 percent of the vote.337
2007 legislative session
In the 2007 session of the Colorado General Assembly, Roberts was a member of the House Health and Human Services Committee and the Joint Legal Services Committee,38 and was the ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee.39
Roberts was one of the most successful Republican legislators at passing legislation through the Democrat-controlled legislature,40 and has been identified by media reports and commentators as a "standout" legislator4142 and a potential candidate for higher office.43 She also organized bowling outings for legislators during her first year in the legislature.44
Roberts carried legislation which revised Colorado's surface rights laws, requiring oil and gas companies to minimize the impacts of drilling.4546 The bill was weakened by lobbying from the Colorado Oil and Gas Association,47 but represented a breadth of reform that had failed to pass in previous legislative sessions.40
During her first legislative session, Roberts also sponsored bills to revise the process by which special health care districts are created48 and to expand eligibility for
Korean War special license plates;49 she cosponsored legislation to fund study of methane seep in southwestern Colorado.50
Her only unsuccessful bill was a measure to tighten the rules under which cigar bars could claim exemptions from Colorado's indoor smoking ban.51 After being killed in committee, the measure was revived in the Colorado Senate by Democrats, but was again unsuccessful.5253
Following the 2007 session, Roberts was named by House Republican leaders to the newly-formed Criminal and Juvenile Justice Commission.54 In November 2007, she was named a Legislator of Merit by the Colorado Behavioral Health Council.55 She joined with other moderate Republicans to criticize an executive order issued by Gov. Bill Ritter allowing collective bargaining with government employee unions as a betrayal of Ritter's promise of bipartisan cooperation on major issues.56
For her voting record during the 2007 legislative session, Roberts earned a 28% rating from the fiscally conservative Colorado Union of Taxpayers57 and an 80% rating from the environmentally-oriented
Colorado Conservation Voters
;58 both ratings placed her closer to average Democratic scores than most Republicans.
2008 legislative session
In the 2008 session of the Colorado General Assembly, Roberts sat on the House Health and Human Services Committee and the House Judiciary Committee. 59 She introduced eight bills during the session, all of which were passed by the legislature.60
During the 2008 legislative session, Roberts introduced a bill, drafted and lobbied for by Colorado students,61 to create a legislative youth advisory council.6263 The bill stalled in the legislature until its minimal cost was approved by the House Appropriations Committee,64 after which it cleared both the House and Senate,65 and Gov. Bill Ritter signed it into law.66 She was later appointed by Minority Leader
Mike May to be one of the legislative members of the council.67
Roberts introduced a bill which would grant advanced practice nurses power to sign off on additional medical forms, in response to shortages of doctors in portions of rural Colorado,68 a measure which garnered support from both nurses' and doctors' associations.69 In March, she backed a proposal to require that insurance companies offer low-cost health care benefit packages for Coloradoans, as part of a "public-private" plan towards achieving universal coverage.70 Roberts was the sponsor of a legislative resolution urging the
Federal Communications Commission to support including southwestern Colorado, including portions of her district, within the
Denver
media market.71
Before the session began, Roberts had expressed interest in sponsoring legislation to revise the process by which the Colorado Constitution is amended through ballot measures, proposing that supermajority popular votes be required to enact amendments.72 She proposed extending the public hearing process as a means of providing additional input on ballot measures,73 and, in February 2008, was appointed to a six-member legislative panel tasked with developing recommendations for constitutional reform.74 She was ultimately a cosponsor of the the panel's proposal to create distinctions in the petition process between constitutional and statutory amendments,75; the proposal which was referred by the legislature to voters 60 and will appear on the November 2008 Colorado ballot as Referendum O.76
Roberts was one of a few Republicans to back a measure to reform spending requirements in Colorado's state constitution. The proposal, which would divert excess revenues under TABOR to K-12 education, was regarded as a sweeping revision to competing constitutional mandates7778; it was not passed by the General Assembly,60 but was advanced as a citizens' initiative.79
2008 election
Roberts was renominated by the Republican Party for a second term in the state house; she faces no challengers either in the Republican primary or in the general election, as no Democratic Party candidates declared their candidacy.8081
